The Obtaining of Eggs and The best method of obtaining very early
stages consists cf removing egg capsules which have been deposited on glass plates
by snails in aquaria. Eggs are visible at the oviuucal opening (anterior meaian
part of foot). After the egg is fastened to glass, the snail may be removed
gently, ana the capsule transferrea to a watch glass of filtered sea water with a
pair uf fine forceps. Since snailsseem to prefer to deposit eggs on the woouen
siues of the tank, in preference to the glass, J. Oppenheimer suggests inserting
sheets ef glass over these sides; these can be removed from the sides for
inspection purposes without disturbing the animals.
The Opening of (The stage of uevelopment of the eggs may be determined
before removal from the capsule with the aid of a binocular microscope.) When
the proper stage is found, pin sown the side of the capsule furthest from the eggs
with a dissecting needle. with another needle, tear off the section that is
pinned tu the dish, making sure that a very large tear is made. If gentle
pressure is now applied to the capsule, the eggs will flow out of the mass of
jelly. Make sure that all cf the eggs are free of the capsule and that the
capsule is rather well torn up before releasing the gressure, or else the thick
jelly will rush back into the capsule, carrying the eggs with it. All of the
operations must be carried out under water, for the eggs rupture on contact with
air. The jelly dissolves in the water, and after a few seconds, the eggs will
settle down to the bottom of the aish.
Qlgayggesz Approximate Time Table:
lobe SO minutes (lst polar body coming off)
Disaap. of lobe 59 minutes (lst polar bony off)
2nd apsears 1 hr. 12 min.
Zno lobe LHS 2 hrs. 12 min.
Bra lobe 2 hrs. 42 min.
cleavage 3 hrs. 42 min.
A cells A hrs. 52 min.
Observe later stages of development through the veliger larva
(there is no trochophore larva.)
REFERENCES

of Ilyanassa. Biol. Bull., QQ:

Ilyanassa. 1. The role of the polar lobe in determination
of the cleavage pattern and its influence in later
uevelonment. J. E. Z. 593.
